The **2018 Commonwealth Games** , officially known as the **XXI Commonwealth
Games** and commonly known as **Gold Coast 2018** , were an
[international](/wiki/International "International") [multi-sport
event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-sport event") for members of the
[Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") that
were held on the [Gold Coast](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland "Gold Coast,
Queensland"), [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland "Queensland"),
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), between 4 and 15 April 2018. It was
the fifth time Australia had hosted the [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") and the first time a
major multi-sport event achieved [gender equality](/wiki/Gender_equality
"Gender equality") by having an equal number of events for males and female
athletes.[1]

More than 4,400 athletes including 300 para-athletes from 71 Commonwealth
Games Associations took part in the event.[2] [The Gambia](/wiki/The_Gambia
"The Gambia") which withdrew its membership from the [Commonwealth of
Nations](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations") and
[Commonwealth Games Federation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games_Federation
"Commonwealth Games Federation") in 2013, was readmitted on 31 March 2018 and
participated in the event .[3] With 275 sets of medals, the games featured 19
[Commonwealth sports](/wiki/Commonwealth_Sports "Commonwealth Sports"),
including [beach volleyball](/wiki/Beach_volleyball "Beach volleyball"), [para
triathlon](/wiki/Paratriathlon "Paratriathlon") and women’s [rugby
sevens](/wiki/Rugby_sevens "Rugby sevens"). These sporting events took place
at 14 venues in the host city, two venues in [Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane
"Brisbane") and one venue each in [Cairns](/wiki/Cairns "Cairns") and
[Townsville](/wiki/Townsville "Townsville").[4]

These were the first Commonwealth Games to take place under the [Commonwealth
Games Federation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games_Federation "Commonwealth Games
Federation") (CGF) presidency of Louise Martin,
[CBE](/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire "Order of the British Empire").[5] The
host city Gold Coast was announced at the CGF General Assembly in
[Basseterre](/wiki/Basseterre "Basseterre"), [Saint Kitts](/wiki/Saint_Kitts
"Saint Kitts"), on 11 November 2011.[6] Gold Coast became the seventh Oceanian
city and the first regional city to host the Commonwealth Games. These were
the eighth games to be held in [Oceania](/wiki/Oceania "Oceania") and the
[Southern Hemisphere](/wiki/Southern_Hemisphere "Southern Hemisphere").

The host nation [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") topped the medal
table for the fourth time in the past five Commonwealth Games, winning the
most golds (80) and most medals overall (198).
[England](/wiki/England_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "England at the 2018
Commonwealth Games") and [India](/wiki/India_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games
"India at the 2018 Commonwealth Games") finished second and third
respectively.[7] [Vanuatu](/wiki/Vanuatu_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games
"Vanuatu at the 2018 Commonwealth Games"), [Cook
Islands](/wiki/Cook_Islands_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Cook Islands at
the 2018 Commonwealth Games"), [Solomon
Islands](/wiki/Solomon_Islands_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Solomon Islands
at the 2018 Commonwealth Games"), [British Virgin
Islands](/wiki/British_Virgin_Islands_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "British
Virgin Islands at the 2018 Commonwealth Games") and
[Dominica](/wiki/Dominica_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Dominica at the 2018
Commonwealth Games") each won their first Commonwealth Games medals.[8]

## Host
selection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Host selection")]

Main article: [Bids for the 2018 Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Bids_for_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Bids for the 2018
Commonwealth Games")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/2018_Commonwealth_Games_countdown_clock_in_July_2017.jpg/220px-2018_Commonwealth_Games_countdown_clock_in_July_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Commonwealth_Games_countdown_clock_in_July_2017.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2018_Commonwealth_Games_countdown_clock_in_July_2017.jpg
"Enlarge")

Countdown clock at [Surfers Paradise](/wiki/Surfers_Paradise,_Queensland
"Surfers Paradise, Queensland")

On 22 August 2008, the [Premier of Queensland](/wiki/Premier_of_Queensland
"Premier of Queensland"), [Anna Bligh](/wiki/Anna_Bligh "Anna Bligh"),
officially launched Gold Coast City's bid to host the Commonwealth Games in
2018. On 7 April 2009, the [ABC](/wiki/Australian_Broadcasting_Corporation
"Australian Broadcasting Corporation") reported a land exchange deal between
Gold Coast City and [State of Queensland](/wiki/Queensland "Queensland") for
[Carrara Stadium](/wiki/Carrara_Stadium "Carrara Stadium"). According to Mayor
[Ron Clarke](/wiki/Ron_Clarke "Ron Clarke"), the land would aid a potential
bid for the 2018 Commonwealth Games. The land exchanged would be used as the
site of an aquatics centre. In the same article, Mayor Clarke raised the
question of the Australian Federal Government's commitment to a 2018
Commonwealth Games bid in light of the Government's support for [Australia's
2018 FIFA World Cup Finals
bid](/wiki/Australian_2018_and_2022_FIFA_World_Cup_bid "Australian 2018 and
2022 FIFA World Cup bid").[9] On 16 April 2009, Queensland Premier Anna Bligh
told reporters that a successful Commonwealth Games bid by Gold Coast City
could help the tourist strip win a role in hosting the World Cup.[10]

"Some of the infrastructure that would be built for the Commonwealth Games
will be useful for Gold Coast City to get a World Cup game out of the soccer
World Cup if we're successful as a nation," she said. However the decision on
the venues for the 2018 and 2022 FIFA World Cups were made eleven months prior
to the bid decision for the 2018 Commonwealth Games, so the potential World
Cup venues had already been chosen. On 3 June 2009, Gold Coast City was
confirmed as Australia's exclusive bidder vying for the 2018 Commonwealth
Games.[11] "Should a bid proceed, Gold Coast City will have the exclusive
Australian rights to bid as host city for 2018," Bligh stated.

"Recently I met with the president and CEO of the Australian Commonwealth
Games Association and we agreed to commission a full and comprehensive
feasibility study into the potential for the 2018 Commonwealth Games," she
said. "Under the stewardship of Queensland Events new chair, [Geoff
Dixon](/wiki/Geoff_Dixon "Geoff Dixon"), that study is now well advanced." On
15 March 2010, it was announced that the Queensland Government will provide
initial funding of A$11 million for the 2018 Commonwealth Games bid. The
Premier of Queensland has indicated the Government's support for the bid to
the Australian Commonwealth Games Association.[12] On 31 March 2010, the
Australian Commonwealth Games Association officially launched the bid to host
the 2018 Commonwealth Games.[13] In October 2011, Gold Coast City Mayor [Ron
Clarke](/wiki/Ron_Clarke "Ron Clarke") stated that the games would provide a
strong legacy for the city after the games have ended.[14]

On 31 March 2010, a surprise bid was made for the 2018 Commonwealth Games by
the [Sri Lankan](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") city of
[Hambantota](/wiki/Hambantota "Hambantota"). Hambantota was devastated by the
[2004 Indian Ocean Tsunami](/wiki/2004_Indian_Ocean_Tsunami "2004 Indian Ocean
Tsunami"), and is undergoing a major face lift. The first phase of the [Port
of Hambantota](/wiki/Port_of_Hambantota "Port of Hambantota") is nearing
completion and it is funded by the government of [China](/wiki/China "China").
The [Mattala International Airport](/wiki/Mattala_International_Airport
"Mattala International Airport"), which is the second international Airport of
Sri Lanka is built close to Hambantota. A new [Hambantota International
Cricket Stadium](/wiki/Hambantota_International_Cricket_Stadium "Hambantota
International Cricket Stadium") had also been built, which had hosted matches
in the [2011 Cricket World Cup](/wiki/2011_Cricket_World_Cup "2011 Cricket
World Cup").

On 10 November 2011, the Hambantota bidders claimed they had already secured
enough votes to win the hosting rights.[15] However, on 11 November it was
officially announced [Gold Coast City](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland "Gold
Coast, Queensland") had won the rights to host the games.[16][17]

##
Administration[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Administration")]

The entire project was overseen by the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games
Corporation (GOLDOC). In February 2012, [Mark
Peters](/wiki/Mark_Peters_\(sport_administrator\) "Mark Peters \(sport
administrator\)") was appointed Chief Executive Officer of the Gold Coast City
2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation.[18] The Queensland Government Minister
tasked with overseeing the Games was [Kate Jones](/wiki/Kate_Jones "Kate
Jones").[19]

##
Preparation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Preparation")]

###
Venues[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Venues")]

Main article: [Venues of the 2018 Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Venues_of_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Venues of the 2018
Commonwealth Games")

One of the key technical aspects of Gold Coast City's successful bid was the
fact that the city had 80 percent of the planned venues in place before the
bidding deadline. The vast majority of venues were located within 20-minutes
driving time of the Athletes Village in [Parkwood](/wiki/Parkwood,_Queensland
"Parkwood, Queensland").

#### Venues in Gold
Coast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Venues in Gold Coast")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/Carrara_Stadium%2C_Gold_Coast%2C_Queensland_02.jpg/220px-
Carrara_Stadium%2C_Gold_Coast%2C_Queensland_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Carrara_Stadium,_Gold_Coast,_Queensland_02.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Carrara_Stadium,_Gold_Coast,_Queensland_02.jpg "Enlarge")

[Carrara Stadium](/wiki/Carrara_Stadium "Carrara Stadium") hosted the
ceremonies and the [athletics](/wiki/Athletics_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games
"Athletics at the 2018 Commonwealth Games")

[Carrara Stadium](/wiki/Carrara_Stadium "Carrara Stadium"), located in the
suburb of [Carrara](/wiki/Carrara,_Queensland "Carrara, Queensland"), was the
main venue for [Athletics](/wiki/Athletics_\(sport\) "Athletics \(sport\)"),
the [opening ceremony](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_opening_ceremony "2018
Commonwealth Games opening ceremony") and the [closing
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_closing_ceremony "2018 Commonwealth
Games closing ceremony"). The seating capacity of the stadium was temporarily
increased to 40,000 for the games by the installation of a large temporary
North Stand.[20]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Gold_coast_convention_and_exhibition_centre.jpg/220px-
Gold_coast_convention_and_exhibition_centre.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gold_coast_convention_and_exhibition_centre.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gold_coast_convention_and_exhibition_centre.jpg "Enlarge")

[Gold Coast Convention and Exhibition
Centre](/wiki/Gold_Coast_Convention_and_Exhibition_Centre "Gold Coast
Convention and Exhibition Centre") hosted
[netball](/wiki/Netball_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games "Netball at the 2018
Commonwealth Games") and the accredited media centre

The [Gold Coast City Convention and Exhibition
Centre](/wiki/Gold_Coast_Convention_and_Exhibition_Centre "Gold Coast
Convention and Exhibition Centre"), located in the suburb of
[Broadbeach](/wiki/Broadbeach,_Queensland "Broadbeach, Queensland"), hosted
[Basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [Netball](/wiki/Netball
"Netball") (preliminaries) and [Weightlifting](/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting
"Olympic weightlifting") events, also serving as the Main Media Centre and
International Broadcast centre hosting over 3000 members of the worlds
press.[21] The Broadbeach Bowls Club hosted the [Bowls](/wiki/Bowls "Bowls")
competition.[22]

The [Hinze Dam](/wiki/Hinze_Dam "Hinze Dam"), located in the suburb of
[Advancetown](/wiki/Advancetown,_Queensland "Advancetown, Queensland"), was
the location for the Mountain Bike competition. A new course was constructed
to meet international competition requirements and temporary spectator seating
for 2,000 spectators.

The newly built [Coomera Sport and Leisure
Centre](/wiki/Coomera_Sport_and_Leisure_Centre "Coomera Sport and Leisure
Centre") hosted [Gymnastics](/wiki/Gymnastics "Gymnastics") and Netball
(finals).[23] The existing sound stages of the Village Roadshow Studios
complex in the suburb of [Oxenford](/wiki/Oxenford,_Queensland "Oxenford,
Queensland") hosted the sports of [Boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"), [Table
Tennis](/wiki/Table_Tennis "Table Tennis") and [Squash](/wiki/Squash_\(sport\)
"Squash \(sport\)").[24] During Games mode the venue was enhanced to provide
for the International Sporting Federation technical venue requirements and
provide spectator seating of 3,000 (boxing) and 3,200 (table tennis). The Gold
Coast Hockey Centre hosted the men's and women's [Hockey](/wiki/Hockey
"Hockey") events during the games.[25] The [Southport Broadwater
Parklands](/wiki/Southport_Broadwater_Parklands "Southport Broadwater
Parklands") hosted [Triathlon](/wiki/Triathlon_at_the_2018_Commonwealth_Games
"Triathlon at the 2018 Commonwealth Games") and athletic events.[26] The
[Optus aquatic centre](/wiki/Gold_Coast_Aquatic_Centre "Gold Coast Aquatic
Centre") hosted the swimming and diving events.[27]

[Robina Stadium](/wiki/Robina_Stadium "Robina Stadium") hosted the [Rugby
7s](/wiki/Rugby_7s "Rugby 7s") competition and upgraded to meet World Rugby
standards.[28] The [Elanora](/wiki/Elanora,_Queensland "Elanora,
Queensland")/[Currumbin Valley](/wiki/Currumbin_Valley "Currumbin Valley")
area hosted the road racing elements of the cycling programme.
[Coolangatta](/wiki/Coolangatta "Coolangatta") Beachfront hosted the beach
volleyball event.[29]

#### Venues outside Gold
Coast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Venues outside Gold Coast")]

[Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane"), along with the Gold Coast, forms part
of the [South East Queensland](/wiki/South_East_Queensland "South East
Queensland") [conurbation](/wiki/Conurbation "Conurbation"). Track Cycling was
held at the [Sleeman Sports Complex](/wiki/Sleeman_Centre_\(Brisbane\)
"Sleeman Centre \(Brisbane\)") in the suburb of
[Chandler](/wiki/Chandler,_Queensland "Chandler, Queensland"), where a new
indoor cycling velodrome (Anna Meares Velodrome) was built. The Velodrome's
seat capacity was 4,000 during the games mode.[30]

The Shooting disciplines were held at the [Belmont](/wiki/Belmont,_Queensland
"Belmont, Queensland") Shooting Centre. In [Tropical North
Queensland](/wiki/Tropical_North_Queensland "Tropical North Queensland"), the
[Cairns Convention Centre](/wiki/Cairns_Convention_Centre "Cairns Convention
Centre") and [Townsville Entertainment
Centre](/wiki/Townsville_Entertainment_Centre "Townsville Entertainment
Centre") hosted the preliminary rounds of both the men's and women's
basketball competitions.[31][32][33]

###
Financing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Financing")]

The [Queensland state government](/wiki/Queensland_State_Government
"Queensland State Government") spent [A$](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian
dollar")1.5 billion ([US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States
dollar")1.2 billion) to deliver the event. Out of this,
[A$](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar")550 million
([US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")425 million) were
spent on the procurement programme. Procurement of the security and security
infrastructure included contracts for four prime suppliers which delivered
around 4,200 security guards. [A$](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian
dollar")34 million ([US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")26
million) were spent on the deployment of the armed forces to provide rapid-
response squads, bomb detectors, offshore patrols and surveillance.
[A$](/wiki/Australian_dollar "Australian dollar")657 million
([US$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar")509 million) were
spent for the construction of the venues and the Games Village.[34]

###
Medals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Medals")]

At a charity gala held on 4 November 2017, the medals for the games were
officially unveiled. Australian Indigenous artist Delvene Cockatoo-Collins
designed the medals, while they were produced by the [Royal Australian
Mint](/wiki/Royal_Australian_Mint "Royal Australian Mint"). The design of the
medals was inspired by the coastline of [Gold
Coast](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Australia "Gold Coast, Australia") along with
Indigenous culture.[35] Furthermore, Cockatoo-Collins mentioned, "the medal
design represents soft sand lines which shift with every tide and wave, also
symbolic of athletic achievement, The continual change of tide represents the
evolution in athletes who are making their mark, Records are made and special
moments of elation are celebrated". Approximately 1,500 medals were created to
be distributed to the medallists and each measures approximately 63
millimetres in diameter. The medals weigh between 138 and 163 grams.[36]

### Athletes
village[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Athletes village")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a0/2018_Commonwealth_Games_Village%2C_Gold_Coast.jpg/300px-2018_Commonwealth_Games_Village%2C_Gold_Coast.jpg)](/wiki/File:2018_Commonwealth_Games_Village,_Gold_Coast.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:2018_Commonwealth_Games_Village,_Gold_Coast.jpg "Enlarge")

2018 Commonwealth Games Village

The 2018 Commonwealth Games Athletes Village was located on 59 hectares at
[Southport](/wiki/Southport,_Queensland "Southport, Queensland"), Gold
Coast.[37] which provided accommodation and services to 6,600 athletes and
officials in 1252 permanent dwellings. There are 1170 one and two bedroom
apartments and 82 three bedroom townhouses which will serve as student
accommodation to the nearby Griffith University. It offered services like
laundry, refreshments and television and computer spaces and four residential
pools. The village consisted a gym which was designed with guidance from the
Australian Institute of Sport and equipment and the equipment were sponsored
by [Technogym](/wiki/Technogym "Technogym"). Adjoining the gym was the Athlete
Recovery Area which provided services like plunge baths, including accessible
baths, saunas, massage and consults from the Sports Medical personnel. The
Main Dining served over 18,000 meals per day to the athletes during the games.
The village also consisted of retail shops, [Optus](/wiki/Optus "Optus") phone
store, salon, bar and a games room which featured a number of arcade games,
pool tables and game consoles.[38]

### Queen's baton
relay[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Queen's baton relay")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b7/Gold_Coast_2018_Queen%27s_Baton.jpg/220px-
Gold_Coast_2018_Queen%27s_Baton.jpg)](/wiki/File:Gold_Coast_2018_Queen%27s_Baton.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Gold_Coast_2018_Queen%27s_Baton.jpg "Enlarge")

[Gold Coast 2018](/wiki/Gold_Coast_2018 "Gold Coast 2018") Commonwealth Games
Baton

The Gold Coast 2018 Queen’s Baton Relay was launched on [Commonwealth
Day](/wiki/Commonwealth_Day "Commonwealth Day"), 13 March 2017, on the
historic forecourt at [Buckingham Palace](/wiki/Buckingham_Palace "Buckingham
Palace"), signalling the official countdown to the start of the Games.
Accompanied by the [Duke of Edinburgh](/wiki/Prince_Philip,_Duke_of_Edinburgh
"Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh") and [Prince
Edward](/wiki/Prince_Edward,_Earl_of_Wessex "Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex")
The Earl of Wessex, Her Majesty [Queen Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II
"Elizabeth II") heralded the start of the relay by placing her ‘message to the
Commonwealth and its athletes’ into the distinctive loop-design Queen’s Baton
which then set off on its journey around the globe. It traveled for 388 days,
spending time in every nation and territory of the Commonwealth. The Gold
Coast 2018 Queen’s Baton Relay was the longest in Commonwealth Games history.
Covering 230,000 km over 388 days, the baton made its way through the six
Commonwealth regions of Africa, the Americas, the Caribbean, Europe, Asia and
Oceania.

The baton landed on Australian soil in December 2017 and then spent 100 days
travelling through Australia, finishing its journey at the Opening Ceremony on
4 April 2018, where the message was removed from the Baton and read aloud by
[Charles, Prince of Wales](/wiki/Charles,_Prince_of_Wales "Charles, Prince of
Wales").[39]

###
Transport[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Transport")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/GCLR_Set_9_at_Broadwater_Parklands_2014-09-28.jpg/220px-
GCLR_Set_9_at_Broadwater_Parklands_2014-09-28.jpg)](/wiki/File:GCLR_Set_9_at_Broadwater_Parklands_2014-09-28.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GCLR_Set_9_at_Broadwater_Parklands_2014-09-28.jpg "Enlarge")

[Gold Coast light rail](/wiki/Gold_Coast_light_rail "Gold Coast light rail")

During the games period, free public transportation within
[Queensland](/wiki/Queensland "Queensland") region was provided to ticket and
accreditation holders. The free transportation services were available on
local buses, train and [Gold Coast light rail](/wiki/Gold_Coast_light_rail
"Gold Coast light rail") ([G:link](/wiki/G:link "G:link")) services in Gold
Coast and on [TransLink](/wiki/TransLink_\(South_East_Queensland\) "TransLink
\(South East Queensland\)") and [Qconnect](/wiki/QConnect "QConnect") bus
services in Cairns and Townsville.[40] The Gold Coast light rail system,
connected a number of the key games venues including the [Optus Aquatic
Centre](/wiki/Gold_Coast_Aquatic_Centre "Gold Coast Aquatic Centre"),
[Broadwater Parklands](/wiki/Southport_Broadwater_Parklands "Southport
Broadwater Parklands") and the [Gold Coast Convention & Exhibition
Centre](/wiki/Gold_Coast_Convention_%26_Exhibition_Centre "Gold Coast
Convention & Exhibition Centre") with the major accommodation centres of
[Surfers Paradise](/wiki/Surfers_Paradise "Surfers Paradise") and
[Broadbeach](/wiki/Broadbeach,_Queensland "Broadbeach, Queensland") and the
Athletes Village at Parklands. An extension to the system was announced in
October 2015, connecting the then current terminus at [Gold Coast University
Hospital](/wiki/Gold_Coast_University_Hospital "Gold Coast University
Hospital") to the [railway line to Brisbane](/wiki/Gold_Coast_railway_line
"Gold Coast railway line") at [Helensvale](/wiki/Helensvale_railway_station
"Helensvale railway station"). The extension opened in December 2017, in time
for the games.[41]

### Anti-
doping[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Anti-doping")]

The [Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority](/wiki/Australian_Sports_Anti-
Doping_Authority "Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority") conducted an anti-
doping drive in the months prior to the games, covering around 2500 tests of
Australian athletes, as well as 500 tests against international athletes.
Three Australians failed drug tests in this process, along with around 20
international athletes, subject to appeal. The Commonwealth Games Federation
conducted in-competition testing and, matching protocol at the [Olympic
Games](/wiki/Olympic_Games "Olympic Games"), launched a sample storage
initiative to allow for future testing of samples up to ten years later,
should detection technology improve.[42]

## Participating
teams[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Participating teams")]

There were 71 nations competing at 2018 Commonwealth Games.[43]
[Maldives](/wiki/Maldives "Maldives") were scheduled to participate, but in
October 2016 they withdrew from the
[Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations "Commonwealth of Nations").[44]
[The Gambia](/wiki/The_Gambia "The Gambia") returned to the Commonwealth Games
after being readmitted as a [Commonwealth Games
Federation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games_Federation "Commonwealth Games
Federation") member on 31 March 2018.[3]

##
Sports[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Sports")]

The regulations stated that from the 26 approved sports administered by
Commonwealth [Governing Bodies](/wiki/Sport_governing_body "Sport governing
body"), a minimum of ten core sports and maximum of seventeen sports must be
included in any Commonwealth Games schedule. The approved sports included the
10 core sports: [athletics](/wiki/Sport_of_athletics "Sport of athletics"),
[badminton](/wiki/Badminton "Badminton"), [boxing](/wiki/Boxing "Boxing"),
[hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey"), [lawn bowls](/wiki/Lawn_bowls
"Lawn bowls"), [netball](/wiki/Netball "Netball") (for women), [rugby
sevens](/wiki/Rugby_sevens "Rugby sevens"), [squash](/wiki/Squash_\(sport\)
"Squash \(sport\)"), [swimming](/wiki/List_of_water_sports "List of water
sports") and [weightlifting](/wiki/Olympic_weightlifting "Olympic
weightlifting"). Integrated [disabled competitions](/wiki/Disabled_sports
"Disabled sports") were also scheduled for the Games in nine sports: swimming,
athletics, cycling, table tennis, powerlifting and lawn bowls. Along with
these events for the first time EAD events in triathlon were held, with the
medals added to the final tally for each nation. A record 38 para events were
contested at these games.[45] On 8 March 2016, [beach
volleyball](/wiki/Beach_volleyball "Beach volleyball") was announced as the
18th sport.[46]

The program was broadly similar to that of the [2014 Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/2014_Commonwealth_Games "2014 Commonwealth Games"), with the
major changes being the dropping of [judo](/wiki/Judo "Judo"), the
reintroduction of [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), the debut of
women's rugby sevens and beach volleyball.[47]

On 7 October 2016, it was announced seven new events for women were added to
the sport program, meaning there are an equal number of events for men and
women. This marks the first time in history that a major [multi-sport
event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-sport event") has equality in terms of
events. In total 275 events in 18 sports are being contested.[48][49]

## Opening
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Opening ceremony")]

Main article: [2018 Commonwealth Games opening
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_opening_ceremony "2018 Commonwealth
Games opening ceremony")

The opening ceremony was held at [Carrara Stadium](/wiki/Carrara_Stadium
"Carrara Stadium") in the [Gold Coast, Australia](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Australia
"Gold Coast, Australia"), between 20:00 and 22:40 AEST, on 4 April 2018.
Tickets for the ceremony started at 100 [Australian
dollars](/wiki/Australian_dollars "Australian dollars") with half price
tickets available for children.[50] The [Head of the
Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the Commonwealth"),
Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II"), was represented by
her son, [Charles, Prince of Wales](/wiki/Charles,_Prince_of_Wales "Charles,
Prince of Wales").[51]

### Parade of
Nations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Parade of Nations")]

Main article: [2018 Commonwealth Games Parade of
Nations](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_Parade_of_Nations "2018 Commonwealth
Games Parade of Nations")

Following tradition, the host of the [previous
games](/wiki/2014_Commonwealth_Games "2014 Commonwealth Games"),
[Scotland](/wiki/Scotland_at_the_2014_Commonwealth_Games "Scotland at the 2014
Commonwealth Games") entered first, followed by the rest of the
[European](/wiki/Europe "Europe") countries competing.[52] Following this, all
countries paraded in alphabetical order from their respective regions. After
the European countries entered, countries from Africa, the Americas, Asia, the
Caribbean, and lastly Oceania marched in. The host nation of Australia entered
last. Each nation was preceded by a placard bearer carrying a sign with the
country's name.

## Closing
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Closing ceremony")]

Main article: [2018 Commonwealth Games closing
ceremony](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_closing_ceremony "2018 Commonwealth
Games closing ceremony")

The closing ceremony was held at Carrara Stadium on Sunday 15th April and was
produced by [Jack Morton Worldwide](/wiki/Jack_Morton_Worldwide "Jack Morton
Worldwide") at a cost of AU$30 million. Australian pop stars [Guy
Sebastian](/wiki/Guy_Sebastian "Guy Sebastian"), [Samantha
Jade](/wiki/Samantha_Jade "Samantha Jade"), [Dami Im](/wiki/Dami_Im "Dami Im")
and [The Veronicas](/wiki/The_Veronicas "The Veronicas") were among the
performers along with children's entertainers, [The Wiggles](/wiki/The_Wiggles
"The Wiggles").

[Prince Edward, Earl of Wessex](/wiki/Prince_Edward,_Earl_of_Wessex "Prince
Edward, Earl of Wessex"), declared the Games closed and passed the
Commonwealth Games flag to [Birmingham, England](/wiki/Birmingham,_England
"Birmingham, England") which will host the [2022
Games](/wiki/2022_Commonwealth_Games "2022 Commonwealth Games").[53]

## Medal
table[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Medal table")]

Main article: [2018 Commonwealth Games medal
table](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games_medal_table "2018 Commonwealth Games
medal table")

Only the top ten successful nations are displayed here.

The ranking in this table is consistent with [International Olympic
Committee](/wiki/International_Olympic_Committee "International Olympic
Committee") convention in its published medal tables. By default, the table is
ordered by the number of gold medals the athletes from a nation have won (in
this context, a "nation" is an entity represented by a [Commonwealth Games
Association](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games_Association "Commonwealth Games
Association")). The number of silver medals is taken into consideration next
and then the number of bronze medals. If nations are still tied, equal ranking
is given and they are listed alphabetically by their three-letter country
code. Australia tops the medal table rank with 80 gold, second England with 45
gold and third India with 26 gold.

##
Broadcasting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Broadcasting")]

In Australia, the games were broadcast live on three [Seven
Network](/wiki/Seven_Network "Seven Network") channels - [7HD](/wiki/7HD
"7HD"), [7TWO](/wiki/7TWO "7TWO") and [7Mate](/wiki/7mate "7mate").[54] In the
United Kingdom, [BBC](/wiki/BBC "BBC") provided Commonwealth Games coverage of
more than 200 hours across [BBC One](/wiki/BBC_One "BBC One"), [BBC
Two](/wiki/BBC_Two "BBC Two"), [BBC Red Button](/wiki/BBC_Red_Button "BBC Red
Button"), [BBC Sport](/wiki/BBC_Sport "BBC Sport") website, [BBC
iPlayer](/wiki/BBC_iPlayer "BBC iPlayer") and [BBC radio](/wiki/BBC_Radio "BBC
Radio").[55] [TVNZ](/wiki/Television_New_Zealand "Television New Zealand")
channel broadcast the games for the viewers in New Zealand.[56] [Astro
Arena](/wiki/Astro_Arena_\(TV_channel\) "Astro Arena \(TV channel\)") provided
the games coverage for the Malaysian viewers.[57] ESPN provided the games
coverage for viewers in the USA.[58] [Sony Pictures Networks
India](/wiki/Sony_Pictures_Networks_India "Sony Pictures Networks India")
broadcast the games for the viewers in India on three channels - [Sony
Six](/wiki/Sony_Six "Sony Six"), [Sony Ten 2](/wiki/Sony_Ten#Sony_Ten_2 "Sony
Ten") in English and [Sony Ten 3](/wiki/Sony_Ten#Sony_Ten_3 "Sony Ten") in
Hindi.[59]

##
Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Marketing")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/6/68/Borobi2018.jpg/220px-
Borobi2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Borobi2018.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Borobi2018.jpg "Enlarge")

Borobi, the mascot of the 2018 Commonwealth Games

###
Motto[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Motto")]

The official motto for the 2018 Commonwealth Games was "Share the Dream". It
was chosen to highlight the dreams and experience at the games that were
shared by participants of the games, ranging from athletes to volunteers and
the host country Australia to the world including the Commonwealth
nations.[60]

###
Emblem[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=24
"Edit section: Emblem")]

The emblem was launched on 4 April 2013, which marked exactly five years until
its opening ceremony.[61] It was unveiled at the [Southport Broadwater
Parklands](/wiki/Southport_Broadwater_Parklands "Southport Broadwater
Parklands"). It was designed by the [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales
"New South Wales") based brand consultancy WiteKite.[62] The emblem of the
2018 Commonwealth Games was a silhouette of the skyline and landscape of Gold
Coast, the host city of the games.[63] Nigel Chamier
[OAM](/wiki/Order_of_Australia "Order of Australia"), who served as the
Chairman of the Gold Coast 2018 Commonwealth Games Corporation till the end of
the games, said that it was the result of months of market research.[64]

###
Mascot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=25
"Edit section: Mascot")]

Main article: [Borobi (mascot)](/wiki/Borobi_\(mascot\) "Borobi \(mascot\)")

Borobi was named as the mascot of the 2018 Commonwealth Games in 2016. Borobi
is a blue koala, with indigenous markings on its body. The term "borobi" means
koala in the [Yugambeh language](/wiki/Yugambeh_language "Yugambeh language"),
spoken by the indigenous [Yugambeh people](/wiki/Yugambeh_people "Yugambeh
people") of the Gold Coast and surrounding areas.[65]

## Concerns and
controversies[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Concerns and controversies")]

### Missing
athletes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: Missing athletes")]

At least 13 athletes from four countries - Cameroon, Uganda, Rwanda, and
Sierra Leone - absconded during or immediately after the Games. Some missed
their competitions.[66] Athletes regularly abscond during major sporting
events, and many subsequently claim asylum in their host countries. Most hold
nationalities that are deemed high-risk by immigration authorities and find it
impossible to get visas outside of exceptional events, such as major
games.[67]

A month after the games ended, officals estimated that fifty athletes had
remained in Australia illegally, with another 200 staying in the country on
visas.[68][69]

### Criticism of the closing
ceremony[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2018_Commonwealth_Games&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Criticism of the closing ceremony")]

The organising committee decided to bring in the athletes before the start of
the closing ceremony. This caused an uproar on social media as, contrary to
public expectations, none of the athletes were shown entering the stadium
during the ceremony. Broadcast rights holders [Channel 7](/wiki/Seven_Network
"Seven Network") complained on air about the decision and concluded that, "it
hasn't really lived up to expectations". Many spectators and athletes left
during the ceremony, resulting in a half-empty stadium for much of the
event.[70] Following this, the [ABC](/wiki/ABC_News_\(Australia\) "ABC News
\(Australia\)") claimed that Channel 7 was briefed on the closing ceremony
schedule,[71] a claim which Channel 7 later refuted.[72]
